;香港国际机场海关人员拘捕30名抵港旅客，涉嫌走私近46公斤据《华盛顿邮报》获悉，今年上半年，警方查获价值 3,900 万港元（500 万美元）的毒品（141 磅）。

;

;被捕人数和检获毒品数量急剧增加，反映出疫情三年后恢复航空旅行以及取消Covid-19限制。

;

;去年上半年，七名入境旅客被捕，并查获5.7公斤毒品，价值590万港元被查获。去年全年共有 20 人被捕。

;

;海关拘捕涉嫌将饼干罐装可卡因走私到香港的男子

;

;熟悉贩毒趋势的消息人士称，随着香港全面重新开放，机场逮捕人数开始上升。

;

;“随着大流行病旅行限制的结束，贩毒集团加大力度利用快递员将非法毒品运入香港，采用不同的隐藏方法和消息人士称。

;

;他表示，自 2021 年初以来，大流行病旅行限制迫使犯罪团伙停止使用快递将非法毒品带入该市。

;

;他补充说，今年的逮捕人数是执法策略和风险评估迅速调整的结果。

;

;临时数字显示，该市查获的五种主要非法毒品——可卡因、大麻、冰毒、海洛因和氯胺酮——今年前 5 个月的缉获量从去年同期的 2,227 公斤猛增三分之二，达到 3,712 公斤。

;

;1 月至 1 月期间可卡因缉获量增加了 228%，达到 1,489 公斤5月份，去年同期为454公斤。

;

;今年上半年在机场查获的毒品大多藏在秘密行李舱内，隐藏在吞服毒品的犯罪嫌疑人体内——填充颗粒，或伪装成食品、乳液和香水。

;

;今年在机场检获的怀疑毒品中，可卡因占大多数。

;

;香港海关检获1,600万港元传动轴内藏有价值氯胺酮

;

;五月，一名来自巴西的66岁男子被捕，并在其行李的床单中发现10公斤怀疑液体可卡因，价值800万港元。他是一周内因涉嫌贩毒而被捕的第五名巴西人。

;

;另一位消息人士称，毒贩知道来自高风险地区的旅客通常会被挑选出来接受检查，因此他们已开始绕道前往香港以避免被发现。

;

;7月8日，一名从澳门乘渡轮抵达香港的24岁男子在海关人员检获约6.3公斤怀疑可卡因后被捕，价值约为他行李中的四个丹麦饼干罐藏着 690 万港元。

;

;他前往香港的“极其复杂”的路线包括在土耳其伊斯坦布尔和埃塞俄比亚亚的斯亚贝巴停留。 .

;

;香港海关查获经新加坡走私的最大宗货物

;

;就在两天前，一名从丹麦哥本哈根抵达的62岁女子在新加坡海关被捕。机场发现价值七百万港元的怀疑可卡因，藏于三个丹麦饼干罐及三个薯片盒内。

;

;由于两宗案件均涉及在饼干罐内藏匿毒品，海关人员正调查两名嫌疑人是否受同一集团招募.

;

;今年涉及航空旅客的最大案件发生在6月25日，一名从马来西亚抵达的42岁女子因在38包琼脂中发现14公斤怀疑可卡因、价值1,500万港元而被捕。

;

;第二名消息人士称，海关将继续与内地及海外执法机构合作及交换情报，打击通过不同渠道贩运毒品。

;< p>;根据《危险药物条例》，贩运最高刑罚为终身监禁及罚款500万港元。

;今年首五个月香港迎来186家公司落户今年，该市商务部长表示，他相信当局能够在三年内实现吸引 1,100 多家企业入驻的目标。

;

;选择在该市落户的企业既有小型企业，也有大型企业商务及经济发展局局长邱英华周日在电视节目中表示，中型企业占大多数。

;

;“一般来说，他们来自创新科技界或创意产业……其中，中小企业相对较多。”丘说。 “首五个月，已有186家企业落户香港，我有信心达到关键绩效指标。”

;

;行政长官李家超在去年施政报告中表示邱腾华的任务是到 2025 年底吸引 1,130 家企业在香港立足，这几乎是每天一家公司。

;

;部长周日提供的数字约占香港企业的 16.5%总体目标。

;

;经过三年的疫情和 2019 年的反政府抗议活动，当局推出了一系列措施，吸引全球人才和企业重振经济。

;

;香港Kong的Paul Chan在上海之行吸引科技公司后暗示“好消息”

;

;这些政策包括推出针对顶尖毕业生和高收入者的新人才计划，以及设立人才办公室吸引战略企业，通过提供特殊奖励来吸引高潜力和代表性企业来到香港。

;

;香港还从未来基金中拨款 300 亿港元（38 亿美元）设立“联合投资基金”，旨在通过商业投资吸引企业来港。

;

;丘周日表示，该办公室在成立后的六个月内已与超过 150 家公司会面，并希望联系另外 300 家公司

;

;“100 家外国公司正在与香港就投资计划进行谈判”

;

;部长补充说，该办公室在与许多公司的讨论中取得了“良好进展”感兴趣的企业。他没有透露更多细节，理由是需要保护相关公司的“商业秘密”。

;

;但感兴趣的各方包括来自中国大陆的企业，以及其他总部位于欧洲和美洲的企业，他说。

;台风逼近，香港人仍热衷于消费今年最新一轮消费券，但一些人表示，他们对周日发放的第二期付款 2,000 港元（256 美元）感到震惊。

;

;财政司司长陈茂波周日上午与几位居民一起使用电子优惠券

;

;“最新一轮消费券将为零售及餐饮业注入约130亿港元的额外消费力”，他在博客中说道。

;

;“该计划实施三年后，电子支付在香港变得更加普遍，覆盖范围更广。电子支付平台上的个人账户增加了1300万个，企业账户增加了22万个。”

;

;他表示，根据香港金融管理局（香港事实上的中央银行）的数据，电子支付平台上的交易总额增加了1300万个。储值支付平台交易金额1,385亿港元，同比增长近25%，交易笔数超过18亿笔。平均交易金额为港币77元。

;

;周日起，合资格永久居民及18岁或以上新来港人士可获赠今年第二期港币2,000元礼券。第一轮3,000港元已于4月中旬派发。

;

;香港电子礼券将于7月16日起发放，但长期计划“困难”

;

;新来港定居人士指成人持有有效的香港身份证，并凭单程许可证（一份允许他们居住在这里的文件）从中国大陆来到香港，或者是获准在香港居住的永久居民的家属。

;

; 继上个月发放 1,500 港元之后，通过各种工作和人才计划以及学习计划来到香港的人士将有资格领取 1,000 港元。

;

;不受即将到来的热带风暴塔利姆的影响，周日早上，点心爱好者聚集在旺角的伦敦餐厅。

;

;一位只透露姓泽的常客表示，她注意到餐厅比平时更拥挤。

;

;“我很高兴，因为我们还有 2,000 港元可以花。”85 岁的老人说道。

;

;“我和朋友们打算点烤乳猪和烤鹅。有了消费券，我们就可以想吃什么就吃什么。没有它，我们就不能这么无忧无虑，吃点心还得省钱。”

;

;Chak说，她本来打算把大部分电子优惠券花在点心和食物上。

;

;“虽然三号台风信号已经发出，但我还是要吃点心。如果我不吃点心我会不高兴。如果我不花掉代金券，我会为自己感到难过，”她说。 “2000港元并不是一个大数目。如果我买电器，剩下的礼券就不够买点心了。”

;

;70岁的退休人员Ada Fong*表示，她很高兴将最新一轮的礼券花在食品上。 .

;

;香港电子优惠券“一闪而过”，提振零售和餐饮业

;

;“至少我们有更多的钱可以花。经济仍然表现不佳，”她说。 “如果政府将来不再推出另一轮也没关系，因为它已经在 Covid-19 大流行上花了很多钱。”

;

;但一些食客对今年的甜味剂感到失望减半至 5,000 港元。

;

;去年，在香港抗击第五波疫情时，当局提供了总价值 10,000 港元的代金券。该计划于 2021 年首次推出，当时发放了 5,000 港元。

;

;40 岁的黄女士是一名教师，当时与父母一起用餐，她表示他们对这笔金额并不感兴趣。

;

;“我对代金券计划没有任何特别的感觉。金额并不大。我们今天不打算在餐厅使用优惠券。我们把钱存起来买电器。”

;

;“如果每次发行总额为5,000港元或10,000港元，买东西会更容易。”

;

; 50岁的家庭主妇黄女士和她的两个朋友表示，他们只会把代金券花在日常用品上。

;

;“我对代金券没什么感觉。或多或少是一样的。我用 2,000 港元做不了多少事，”她说。 “如果我必须依靠这2000港元，那就有问题了。我们不打算用它来支付餐费。”

;

;该计划中的六家支付平台提供商是八达通、中国银行的 BOC Pay、汇丰银行的 PayMe、AlipayHK、Tap & Go 和微信 Pay HK。

;

;AlipayHK 归蚂蚁集团所有，而蚂蚁集团是《南华早报》所有者阿里巴巴集团的附属公司。

;

;*应受访者要求更改了姓名。

; Sun, 16 Jul 2023 15:20:03 +0800 Hong Kong insurance industry’s new capital rules will lift risk management standards as uncertainty grips capital marketshttps://www.scmp.com/business/article/3227737/hong-kong-insurance-industrys-new-capital-rules-will-lift-risk-management-standards-uncertainty?utm_source=rss_feed

;香港对保险公司的新资本要求为本地保险公司制定了严格的条件，但业内人士表示，这些新规定还将改善风险管理，并加强香港作为国际保险中心的地位。

;

;香港立法者于 7 月 6 日通过了一项新法案，将为保险业提供立法框架。保险业监管局上周在一份声明中表示，该市将于明年为当地保险业引入基于风险的资本（RBC）制度。

;

;新法律确保保险公司根据风险维持适当的资本和偿付能力水平。当局旨在促进行业财务稳健。

;

;在新制度下，保险公司将需要根据风险水平注入额外资本其产品的期限和性质，短期产品和简单索赔需要较少的资本，而有保证付款的长期保单则需要较高的资本支持。这取代了目前更加规则化的资本要求标准。

;

;“新的资本要求确实是一个很大的变化，每个保险公司都在忙着弄清楚如何应对新的变化。”专注于为该地区保险公司提供服务的资产管理公司Conning Asia-Pacific首席执行官Ruby Yang。

;

;“这将确保保险公司有足够的资金来支付客户的费用，无论市场状况如何。这将让保险公司更好地应对不确定性，进而有助香港巩固其国际保险中心的地位。”

;

;香港可以超越伦敦、新加坡成为全球保险中心< /h3>;

;Conning Asia-Pacific 是美国资产管理公司 Conning 的一部分，该公司管理着超过 2000 亿美元的资产。该公司代表保险公司进行投资，并为他们提供先进的投资管理工具。

;

;“由于资本市场非常难以预测，保险公司需要复杂的计算和预测来管理其投资组合。任何公司都无法像以前那样手动完成这项工作，”她说。 “他们需要工具和定量流程来帮助他们进行分析。”宏利金融亚洲主席达米安·格林（Damien Green）表示，新要求是政府推广机构金融服务发展委员会的成员。将使香港与国际标准接轨。

;

;“许多海外市场，特别是欧洲市场，已经采用了基于风险的资本要求，”格林说。

;

;“这种新的风险以香港为基础的资本制度将使香港处于全球金融市场的前沿，有利于香港保险业及其客户的长远发展。” “这是巩固香港作为国际金融和风险管理中心地位的关键一步。”

;

;除了新的资本要求外，康宁的杨表示，她的公司还看到来自印度、新加坡的保险公司的强劲需求

;

;“大湾区的机遇，以及‘一带一路’倡议的众多项目，在过去的几个月里，为香港和中国大陆重新开放边境带来了机遇。”增加了对各种保险的需求。香港是提供这种保险的理想地点。”杨说。

;

;出生于北京的杨于 2010 年移居香港，他对香港行政长官李家超的发展目标充满信心

;

;杨女士拥有20多年的金融行业经验，于2017年加入康宁，负责中国业务，并于今年3月晋升至现职。 。她还曾在贝莱德资产管理公司、工银国际、花旗银行和三井住友银行工作过。

;

;“我们对商机持乐观态度，预计今年下半年的业务活动将比疫情前更好”杨说。

;

;“香港的资金自由流动、理想的地理位置、全球认可的法律体系和丰富的人才库，将吸引更多热衷于在这一地区发展业务的国际保险公司世界。”

;马来西亚在亚洲 10 个最安全的退休地点中排名第一总部位于美国的金融服务公司纳斯达克。

;

;该公司最近在其 GoBankingRates 部分的一篇文章中表示，这一发现是基于联合国亚太地区集团和国内生产总值 (GDP) 的数据来自 WorldPopulationReview 的数据。

;

;它还获得了来自 Numbeo 的生活成本数据以及来自经济与和平研究所全球和平指数 2022 年报告的全球和平指数 (GPI)。

;

;GPI 衡量的是和平国家和地区的相对地位，以及国家卷入持续的国内和国际冲突的程度，旨在评估一个国家内部和谐或不和谐的程度。

;

;纳斯达克还据马新社报道，开创先例，各国的全球和平指数必须低于 2.0 才能获得资格。

;

;排名第一的是马来西亚，其全球和平指数为 1.471，平均每月生活成本为 1,066 美元.

;

;“马来西亚以22.9的生活成本指数和481.9万亿美元的GDP位居第一。平均每月开支略高于 1,000 美元，对于退休人员来说是一个绝佳的考虑地点，”它表示。排名第二的是科威特，全球和平指数为1.739，月平均生活成本为1,741美元。

;

;科威特的生活成本并不像其他一些国家那么低。在这份名单上，排名为 37.4，但其总体生活成本加上全球和平得分使其成为退休的好地方。

;

;根据纳斯达克指数，排名第三的是蒙古，和平指数为 1.775，每月平均生活成本为 940 美元，并补充说，蒙古的生活成本与印度尼西亚并列最低，为 20.2，但其国内生产总值 (GDP) 为最低，为 21 万亿美元。

;

;排名第四的是越南，和平指数为1.786，平均每月生活成本为1,117美元，其次是印度尼西亚，和平指数为1.800，平均每月生活成本为940美元。柬埔寨和尼泊尔也跻身前十。

; Sun, 16 Jul 2023 15:20:03 +0800 ChatGPT helps Hong Kong students with critical thinking, but teachers stay ahead with human touchhttps://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/education/article/3227884/chatgpt-helps-hong-kong-students-critical-thinking-teachers-stay-ahead-human-touch?utm_source=rss_feed

;香港老师何洁莹递交表格时充满期待五名中文学生的平板电脑配备了 ChatGPT，这是一种备受争议但功能强大的人工智能 (AI) 工具。

;

;全班必须分析已故中国作家习习的短篇小说《像我这样的女人》，讲述一位太平间化妆师准备在一家咖啡馆向她的新男友透露她的职业的故事。

;

;Ho 希望学生询问 ChatGPT 它认为男友会如何反应。

;

;“我的目标是鼓励我的学生运用批判性思维和创造力来评估和解释人工智能生成的回答。”已经教中文 13 年的何说。

;

; Sun, 16 Jul 2023 14:20:02 +0800 Cambodia’s Hun Sen poised to extend 38-year rule, without his favoured platform Facebookhttps://www.scmp.com/week-asia/politics/article/3227686/cambodias-hun-sen-poised-extend-38-year-rule-without-his-favoured-platform-facebook?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.07.16 14:00;
;;

;世界上任职时间最长的领导人之一柬埔寨洪森即将换届本月晚些时候，在他禁止反对派并拆除大部分自由媒体后，他以压倒性的选举结果获得一致胜利。

;

;但在他退出 Facebook 平台后，他也将在没有他最喜欢的通讯工具 Facebook 的情况下参加民意调查。他拥有 1400 万追随者。

;

;洪森和他的柬埔寨人民党 (CPP) 是一名前红色高棉指挥官，他在残暴政权结束时倒戈并自 1985 年以来一直领导国家由于反对党烛光党在 5 月份因技术问题而被禁止参加选举，因此几乎没有遭到反对。

;

;这使得选票上几乎没有留下任何有意义的反对派，几乎保证了洪森 38 年的统治将得到延长。< /p>;

;尽管已经消除了对他任期的威胁，这位 70 岁的老人仍然处于战斗状态：警告政界、民间社会和媒体的竞争对手，他有能力随意摧毁他们。

;

;He has even scratched at social media giant Meta, which pulled one of his posts on Facebook – Cambodia's main social media platform – for inciting violence.

;

;Experts say it is typical of an authoritarian leader with nearly four decades ruling the Southeast Asian kingdom under his belt, but who lashes out with increasing unpredictability, often pushing unsubstantiated rumours of outside forces intent on destabilising Cambodia to emboss his own credentials as the country's touchstone politician.

;

;Hun Sen deleted his Facebook page on June 29 soon after Meta's oversight board deemed a combative speech – posted on his timeline – to be threatening violence and called for the post to be removed following complaints it violated Facebook community standards.

;

;What next for Cambodia's US ties, China trade after Hun Sen's certain poll win?

;

;The speech had warned he could come after opposition officials with “legal means” or a “stick”.

;

;Explaining his sudden exit, Hun Sen said he was “finished using Facebook”, blaming false accounts and the next day warned he might block the platform “for a short period or forever” – an empty threat in a country where Facebook is the bedrock of internet use .

;

;But on July 4, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs blacklisted 22 members of the company's oversight board and barred them from entering the country.

;

;“Hun Sen is so used to total domination … any questioning of his actions sets him off wildly,” said Joshua Kurlantzick, a senior fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations think tank studying Southeast Asia.

;

;Meta's decision likely bothered the Cambodian leader because “it was one outlet that Hun Sen did not totally control”, he said.

;

;“It also speaks to the increasing authoritarianism of his regime in recent years, in which there is now no contestation,” Kurlantzick added.

;

;Both Meta and the Oversight Board said they didn't have a response to Cambodia's opposition to their decision to take down Hun Sen's post.

;

;

;

;Without Facebook, Hun Sen's daily deluge of hectoring speeches is not reaching his 14 million former followers on the platform.

;

;He has moved to Telegram and reactivated his Twitter account, but neither platform has the same penetration in Cambodia, where the internet for many pivots around Facebook.

;

;Government-backed news outlets, politicians and even tycoons are still posting aligned messages on their Facebook pages, sharing posts about public figures and NGOs, with boxing teams pledging to vote in the election and not support “toxic politicians”.

;

;Officials are urging their followers to spend more time on Telegram and TikTok, where Hun Sen has taken up digital residency.

;

;Young Cambodians say the Facebook controversy has highlighted the relegation of debate and policy details behind personality politics.

;

;“During this political campaign we only see CPP … but we don't see anything about their actions, their policy, they just tell [netizens] to go and vote for the party, they don't say what they're going to do for the next five years,” said Chhun Theareach, a 21-year-old university student and member of the informal discussion and debate group Politikoffee.< /p>;

;Cambodia's Hun Sen wants 'back in Beijing's orbit' amid US balancing act

;

;Despite their prolific use of the platform, Cambodians are also cautious about posting on Facebook, aware of the risks of unwanted attention from their peers, or even the authorities – opposition members and activists have been charged with a range of incitement cases solely for their Facebook posts.

;

;“Some users are not willing to express their opinion about political parties or campaigns,” he said.

;

;But he said he had noticed more young Cambodians being prompted to speak out online about the risks of life without Facebook following Hun Sen's as yet empty threat to ban Meta's platforms, with the potential to spur wider debate.

;

;“[Young Cambodians] are informed, but they don't have the space or environment where they can freely express their opinion,” he said.

;

;< /h3>;

;Hun Sen's CPP is expected to take all 125 National Assembly seats up for grabs in the July 23 polls, as it did in 2018 after the government had orchestrated a takedown of rising opposition coalition the Cambodian National Rescue Party the previous autumn.

;

;This time, the new opposition Candlelight Party – which can trace its origins back to the controversial but popular figure Sam Rainsy – has also been banned from competing in this election.

;

; But unlike previous elections, Hun Sen is increasingly hinting at his retirement and indicating that he wants to hand power to his son Hun Manet without conflict or dissent from any corner of Cambodian society.

;

;Cambodia's leader in waiting: US military-educated, but China's man?

;

;Hun Sen's supporters say he stabilised a broken, poor country and has steered economic growth with major infrastructure and construction schemes, reshaping a nation ruined by war genocide and chronic corruption.< /p>;

;But critics say much of the wealth created has been shared among a narrow elite. Others accuse Hun Sen of allowing Cambodia to become an effective client state of China, with vast tracts of land and resources sold to Chinese businesses – while shady Chinese investors and gangsters have found a money-spinning haven in casinos and scam centres dotting the country.

;

;Throughout, the authoritarian strongman has been busy insisting to Cambodia's nearly 17 million people that his leadership was what led to all the country's gains.

;

;Vote or you'll be barred from running in all future elections, says Cambodian PM

;

;Even without a tenable opposition party, Hun Sen's government is working overtime to breed election enthusiasm and stifle dissent.

;

;Cambodia's parliament rushed through a new law designed to press people to the polls and enact a vaguely-worded charge against those who “incite” citizens not to vote – likely aimed at exiled opposition stalwart and Hun Sen's nemesis Sam Rainsy, who has called on Cambodians to destroy their ballots.

;

;With the vote looming, Hun Sen will be “sorely missing” his Facebook page, said Phil Robertson of Human Rights Watch's Asia Division.

;

;Applauding the decision by the Oversight Board, Robertson said the platform, which is “arguably the public square of Cambodia social media life”, will be a better place without Hun Sen's “political vitriol, and intimidation tactics”.

; Sun, 16 Jul 2023 14:20:02 +0800 Social anxiety and wanderlust are among Covid-19 pandemic’s lingering impact on Hong Konghttps://www.scmp.com/comment/opinion/article/3227654/social-anxiety-and-wanderlust-are-among-covid-19-pandemics-lingering-impact-hong-kong?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.07.16 13:30;
;;

;A recent holiday in Thailand got me reflecting on just how much damage the Covid-19 pandemic has done to all of us. A series of studies and surveys are showing just how deep the hurt has been, and how the effects continue to linger for many people.

;

;The immediate purpose of the visit was to see my three grandchildren who live in Bangkok. Of course, we kept in touch over the phone during the period international travel basically shut down. But seeing a distant face on a small screen is not the same as seeing that person in the flesh, with the opportunity of a spontaneous hug.

;

;Checking the dates of the last visit from passport chops, I realised with a sense of horror we had not been physically close for more than three years. In the interim, two of the children had become teenagers and the third had reached double figures in age. I had missed out on some of their most formative years.

;

;But it's not only me, and it's not only Thailand. We have all had three years ripped out of our lives. That is time we will never get back.

;

;The ultimate loss was suffered by the millions who actually died, and we should mourn their passing. But the immediate family of the deceased and close friends also suffered a loss, their grief severe and made especially acute if the obstacles to international travel removed the opportunity for a last goodbye.

;

;Some patients are also reporting a long-term sense of fatigue and loss of memory. The phenomenon of what has been called “long Covid” will no doubt be studied in the months and years ahead.

;

;The adverse long-term effects on the education of our young people have been emerging. Children have been arriving for class unable to socialise. Older students have had their education seriously disrupted by repeated suspension of classes, and lessons via Zoom are no substitute for in-person teaching. The worst days are behind us and things are now returning to normal, but it will take time for the negative effects to fade.

;

;So where are we now? Looking around, the most striking thing immediately visible is surely the continued preponderance of people wearing masks. A degree of caution in early March was perhaps understandable, but more than four months after the mandate was lifted? From personal observation, I would estimate around half of the passengers on public transport continue to mask up.

;

;A case can be made for a more conservative approach on a crowded train, but what are we to make of the private car driver alone in his vehicle or the solo pedestrian on an otherwise empty footpath? I even see people doing vigorous exercises in the gym with their faces covered, directly contrary to World Health Organization advice.

;

;Here in the Mid-Levels, we are surrounded by secondary schools and every day, in the middle of summer with temperatures well above 30 degrees Celsius and humidity through the roof, hundreds of children can be seen gasping for air as they struggle to get to class. A few have started to go mask-free, but most still wear them. We must ask why.

;

;A study conducted by the Evangelical Lutheran Church Social Service might give part of the answer. More than 80 per cent of the pupils surveyed continue to wear masks, and the biggest reason quoted was health concerns. Parental influence was another prominent factor, but the second-most common reason given was cause for concern: lack of confidence in their personal appearance.

;

;Many of our youngsters are continuing to mask up because of social anxiety. When only eyes can be seen, everyone is pretty much equal. But when the masks come off, people can and will be compared to their peers in terms of physical attractiveness.

;

;A separate study, conducted by the Institute of Higher Education and Chinese University, found that more than half of primary and secondary students surveyed had moderate to severe depression or stress issues. The study was looking for a possible link between mental health and playing video games online.

;

;A different survey, this time by online travel agency Klook, also had interesting results. Adults were asked about their travel plans for the next 12 months and 96 per cent said they were planning to be on the move somewhere. They are also ready to spend more, and trip length was growing, too. Moreover, the lead time for planning the trips is getting shorter: when Hongkongers feel like travelling, they want to go right now.

;

;Putting all these pieces of the puzzle together, we start to get a picture of the effects of the pandemic on Hongkongers' mindset. They are worried. They have had a fresh reminder of the impermanence of life, have just lost three years of it and feel there's no time to lose.

;

;Each of us will take different lessons from the pandemic experience. I will look with more sympathy on those who continue to show signs of anxiety or depression. And I plan to spend a lot more time with my family, to hell with the expense.

; Sun, 16 Jul 2023 13:50:02 +0800 Importance of US-India ties shown with Janet Yellen’s latest trip amid China tensionshttps://www.scmp.com/news/asia/south-asia/article/3227875/importance-us-india-ties-shown-janet-yellens-latest-trip-amid-china-tensions?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.07.16 13:13;
;;

;On the heels of a trip to Beijing, US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen is back in India for the third time in nine months, this time to meet finance ministers from the G20 about global economic challenges like the increased threat of debt defaults facing low-income countries.

;

;Yellen will use her time in Gandhinagar to try to foster warming relations between the US and India. She also plans a stop in Hanoi, Vietnam, to address supply chain reliability, clean energy transition and other matters of economic resilience.

;

;Yellen's goals for her time in India: press for debt restructuring in developing countries in economic distress, push to modernise global development banks to make them more climate-focused and deepen the ever-growing US-India relationship.

;

;Yellen's frequent stops in the country signal the importance of that relationship at a time of tensions with China.

;

;India's long-standing relationship with Russia also will loom as the Kremlin's invasion of Ukraine continues despite US and allied countries' efforts to sanction and economically bludgeon Russia's economy.

;

;India, which chairs the G20 this year, has not taken part in the efforts to punish Russia and maintains energy trade with that country despite a G7 agreed-upon price cap on Russian oil, which has seen some success in slowing Russia's economy.

;

;Still, the US increasingly relies on India and has courted its leaders.

;

;President Joe Biden hosted a White House state visit honouring Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi in June, designed to highlight and foster ties. The two leaders pronounced the US-India relationship never stronger and rolled out new business deals between the nations.

;

;Raymond Vickery Jr., a policy expert on US-India relations at the Center for Strategic and International Studies, said Yellen's coming to India soon after visiting China is meaningful in that Indian officials “are going to want to know in great detail what happened in the meetings with her Chinese counterparts and see where it fits with their perspective on economic relations with China.”

;

;“They're going to want to know whether the United States is serious about moving some of its sourcing activity from China to India.”

;

;A senior Treasury official, speaking on condition of anonymity to preview Yellen's trip, said there was hope that debt treatments for Ghana and Sri Lanka will be discussed and completed quickly at the meetings.

;

;Sri Lanka and Ghana defaulted on their international debts last year, roughly two years after Zambia defaulted. And more than half of all low-income countries face debt distress, which hurts their long-term ability to function and develop.

;

;Last month, Zambia and its government creditors, including China, reached a deal to restructure US$6.3 billion in loans, on the sidelines of a global finance summit in Paris.

;

;The agreement covers loans from countries such as France, the UK, South Africa, Israel and India as well as China – Zambia's biggest creditor at US$4.1 billion of the total. The deal may provide a road map for how China will handle restructuring deals with other nations in debt distress.

;

;Yellen's trip comes soon after she spent a week in China, meeting the nation's finance ministry and discussing mutual trade restrictions and national security concerns.

;

;Harold W. Furchtgott-Roth, a senior fellow at the Hudson Institute, said Yellen's trip to India “is a reflection of a naturally developing alliance.”

;

;“India has a great deal of tension with China – they have constant border disputes,” he said.”

;

;“And India wants to develop and has developed into sort of an Indian Ocean naval power, which is also a region that China wants to develop.”

;Heatwaves that have left many countries sweltering since early April will continue to drive temperatures to record-breaking levels for the rest of the year as warming due to rising greenhouse-gas emissions coincides with the onset of the cyclical El Nino weather phenomenon, according to climate scientists.

;

;It is, however, difficult to decipher how much of the impact can be attributed to El Nino, which historically exacerbates extreme heatwaves on land and in the oceans, versus the effects of climate change.

;

;“We are in uncharted territory, and we can expect more records to fall as El Nino develops further,” Christopher Hewitt, director of climate services at the World Meteorological Organisation (WMO), said in a statement on Monday. “These impacts will extend into 2024. This is worrying news for the planet.”

;

;Underscoring the urgency, the president-designate of the United Nations' Climate Change Conference (COP28) this week released a four-pillar plan with “fast-tracking transition” as its top priority ahead of the annual conference in Dubai in November.

;

;The week to July 9 was the warmest the world has seen since record-keeping began, according to data collected by satellites, land-based stations and ships and analysed by the WMO. That followed the hottest June ever.

;

;On July 7, the world's average temperature was 17.24 degrees Celsius, shattering the previous record of 16.94 degrees set on August 16 of 2016, data from the Japan Meteorological Agency showed.

;

;Antarctic sea ice was at its lowest level for June since satellite surveillance started, at 17 per cent below average, the WMO noted.

;

;El Nino is a natural climate pattern in the Pacific Ocean that brings warmer sea-surface temperatures, often leading to heatwaves, droughts and floods around the world.

;

;It occurs on average every two to seven years, with episodes lasting nine to 12 months, according to the US National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.

;

;“Global warming has been shown to increase the likelihood of extreme temperature events,” said Francis Tam, associate professor of earth system science, and Cao Dingrui, PhD candidate, at Chinese University of Hong Kong. “El Nino can further exacerbate the occurrence of severe heatwaves in some regions.

;

;“However, accurately quantifying the separate contributions of human-induced global warming and El Nino to hot events is still scientifically challenging.”

;

;Heatwaves have become regular occurrences in recent years. This year, South and Southeast Asia got hit as early as mid-April, when record-breaking temperatures were reported in India, Bangladesh, southwest China, Laos, Thailand, Myanmar, Singapore and Vietnam.

;

;In June, a hot spell hit northern China. Beijing saw daily high temperatures of at least 35 degrees on 16 days of the month, culminating on June 22 with a record June reading of 41.1 degrees.

;

;A prolonged heatwave that scorched swathes of southern Europe, sending daytime highs to between the mid-30s and mid-40s last week, is forecast to continue until the end of the month.

;

;In the southern US state of Texas, a stagnant high-pressure system that caused temperatures to spike five or more degrees above average for much of last month is forecast to last until late this month.

;

;In Hong Kong, July yielded 10 very hot days – with maximums above 33 degrees – by July 15.

;

;As global temperatures rise, can cities withstand extreme heat?

;

;There is a two in three chance that between this year and 2027, the annual average global temperature will exceed 1.5 degrees above pre-industrial levels for at least one of the five years, the WMO said in May.

;

;Under the Paris agreement signed by nearly 200 nations in 2016, global leaders have committed to contain global warming to well below 2 degrees, and to strive to keep it at 1.5 degrees by implementing decarbonisation policies.

;

;However, policies in place as of last November around the world would result in 2.7 degrees of warming, according to Climate Action Tracker.

;

;

;One of the most unusual heatwaves this year is taking place in the northeastern Atlantic Ocean, which saw record-high sea-surface temperatures last month: 1.36 degrees above average for the month.

;

;Short-term abnormal circulation in the atmosphere and longer-term changes in the ocean caused the surge, according to European Union-backed research institute Copernicus Climate Change Service.

;

;Such marine heatwaves could have serious consequences for the trajectory and intensity of hurricanes in the summer, as well as mid-latitude cyclones in the winter, said Gabriel Lau Ngar-cheung, professor emeritus at the Chinese University of Hong Kong's department of geography and resource management.

;

;They can also lead to severe and persistent impacts on marine ecosystems, such as changes in phytoplankton blooms, toxic algal blooms and declines in fish catches, said Richard Betts, chair in climate impacts at the UK's University of Exeter.

;

;Meanwhile, in East Asia, a southeastward shift in the origin points of tropical cyclones, as well as a later than normal onset to the typhoon season, can be expected in a typical El Nino year, said Tam and Cao.

;

;El Nino typically leads to both more intense and longer lasting typhoons, Betts said. More of them would make landfall at higher latitudes, such as northeast China, South Korea and Japan, while fewer would tend to hit further south, in the Philippines, southern China and Vietnam, he added.
